data.title: EPA Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) Program
data.meta_description: The goal of the EPA UAS program is to create a framework through which EPA Regions, Program offices and grant recipients can take advantage of UAS technology to protect human health and the environment.
data.text:
The goal of the EPA UAS program is to create a framework through which EPA regional offices, EPA headquarters offices and grant recipients can take advantage of UAS technology to protect human health and the environment. UAS offer data collection advantages by:

Increasing safety

Affording operators safe monitoring distances

Affording operators an opportunity to identify the location of hazards before entering into a hazardous zone

Accessing difficult or dangerous to access locations with minimal risk

Reducing costs

Providing cost-effective data

Deploying fewer personnel

Increasing efficiency

Can be quickly deployed (hours not days)

Monitoring multiple locations simultaneously with fewer personnel

Deploying additional technologies for data collection and research, such as:

High Resolution Imagery: optical photo/video, infrared/thermal, and multispectral

Geophysics and remote sensing: LiDAR, magnetometry, and ground-penertrating radar

Gas Sensors : H2S, SO2, NO, NO2, HCHO, VOCs, CO, Cl, HCl, HCN, NH3, CH3, dioxins, particulates, and more

ERT VIPER integration, for real-time data collection and transmission

Where We Work

EPA works across the United States to fulfill its mission of protecting human health and the environment. View general information on what EPA is doing in your state.

EPA may use UAS for work, such as:

Reconnaissance, response & mapping

Ability to operate in hazardous situations

Structural integrity assessment

Investigating releases and chemical, biological, radiological events

Logistics and planning support

Site mapping (aerials for pre, post, or ongoing site documentation, volume/3D)

Terrain modeling (erosion, deforestation, forest mapping, riverbanks)

EPA's UAS Community of Practice

EPA has an EPA UAS Community of Practice made up of staff from across the Agency

The purpose of the EPA UAS Community of Practice is to:

Share UAS news, requirements, experiences and technical information

Standardize UAS use practices across EPA

Build a technical and practical knowledge base
